title: AWS, Microsoft and Google unite behind Linux Foundation DocumentDB database to cut enterprise costs and limit vendor lock-in
optimized_headline: Tech Giants Collaborate on DocumentDB to Reduce Costs and Vendor Lock-In
raw_excerpt: Enterprise data teams get vendor-neutral open source document database backed by cloud computing giants .
raw_body: Enterprise data teams get vendor-neutral open source document database backed by cloud computing giants .
speedrun: AWS, Microsoft, and Google are collaborating on a new open-source document database under the Linux Foundation. This initiative aims to help businesses reduce costs and avoid being tied to a single vendor. With major cloud players backing this, it could reshape how companies manage their data.
why_it_matters: This new database offers enterprise data teams a cost-effective, flexible solution, reducing reliance on specific vendors.
The collaboration signals a shift in the tech landscape, promoting open-source solutions that can drive competition and innovation.

lenses.eli12: Imagine if your favorite apps could work together without worrying about which company made them. That's what AWS, Microsoft, and Google are doing with a new open-source database. It helps businesses save money and avoid being stuck with one provider. This matters because it gives everyday users more choices and better services.
lenses.pm: For product managers, this new open-source database provides an opportunity to meet user needs for flexibility and cost-efficiency. It can enhance product offerings by integrating with various cloud services without vendor lock-in. A practical next step is to explore how this database can be incorporated into existing products to improve user experience.
lenses.engineer: This collaboration among major cloud providers aims to create a vendor-neutral document database, which could simplify data management for enterprises. The approach focuses on open-source principles, encouraging community contributions. However, potential limitations include the need for robust support and documentation, which are crucial for widespread adoption.
